questions.solution:
Ans. C. Asbestosis

 

 

Option C:

 

Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers. Ferruginous bodies are specifically associated with asbestos exposure. These bodies are formed when iron-containing proteins coat asbestos fibers in the lungs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica dust.

 

Option B: Byssinosis: Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease" or "Monday fever," is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of cotton, flax, or hemp dust.

 

Option D: Bagassosis: Bagassosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of dust from moldy sugarcane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ferruginous bodies are not typically associated with silicosis, byssinosis and bagassosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 701)

questions.text: All of the following are seen in asbestosis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diffuse alveolar damage

 

Option A:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage: is not a typical finding in asbestosis. Asbestosis is characterized by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis rather than diffuse alveolar damage. Diffuse alveolar damage is more commonly associated with conditions such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Calcified pleural plaques: This is a characteristic feature of asbestosis. Asbestos exposure can lead to the formation of pleural plaques, which are areas of fibrous thickening and calcification on the pleura. These plaques are a hallmark of asbestos-related lung disease.

 

Option C: Diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis: This is a correct option. Asbestosis is primarily characterized by the deposition of asbestos fibers in the lungs, leading to pulmonary fibrosis. It involves the interstitium of the lungs, causing scarring and impairment of lung function.

 

Option D: Mesothelioma: This is a correct option. Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for the development of mesothelioma, a malignant tumor of the mesothelial cells lining the pleura, peritoneum, and other serosal surfaces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage is not typically associated with asbestosis but is more indicative of acute conditions such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), distinguishing it from the chronic fibrotic changes seen in asbestosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 672)

questions.text: An elderly coal miner with a history of smoking and emphysema develops severe air-flow obstruction and expires. His autopsy reveals a “black lung,” with coal-dust nodules scattered throughout the parenchyma and a central area of dense fibrosis. The coal dust entrapped within this miner’s lung was sequestered primarily by which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrophages

 

Option D:

Coal workers’ pneumoconiosis reflects the inhalation of carbon particles. The characteristic pulmonary lesions of simple coal worker’s pneumoconiosis include non palpable coal-dust macules and palpable coal dust nodules, both of which are typically multiple and scattered throughout the lung as 1- to 4-mm black foci. These nodules have dust-laden macrophages associated with a fibrotic stroma. The other options are not phagocytic cells.

 

Macrophages are phagocytic cells that play a crucial role in the body's defense against inhaled particulates. In the lungs, they are responsible for engulfing and sequestering foreign particles, such as coal dust, and can become laden with these particles, contributing to the formation of coal-dust nodules.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Endothelial cells line the blood vessels and are involved in the exchange of substances between the bloodstream and surrounding tissues.

 

Option B. Fibroblasts are the main cell type involved in tissue repair and fibrosis. In response to lung injury, they produce the extracellular matrix and collagen leading to fibrosis, but they do not phagocytose foreign materials such as coal dust.

 

Option C. Lymphocytes, including T and B cells, are primarily involved in the immune response against pathogens and are not known for phagocytosing materials like coal dust.

 

Educational Objective

 

In conditions such as coal workers' pneumoconiosis, also known as "black lung," macrophages are the primary cells responsible for sequestering coal dust. They phagocytose the dust particles and become the centre of coal-dust nodules, which may lead to lung fibrosis.

questions.text: A patient with squamous cell carcinoma of lung has undergone pneumonectomy. During the procedure blackish hilar lymph node of 1 cm is seen. Identify the cause of pigmentation:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anthracotic pigment

Option A:

Anthracotic pigment: Anthracotic pigment is due to the accumulation of carbon particles from smoking or environmental pollution and is commonly seen in the lungs and hilar lymph nodes of urban dwellers and smokers.

Explanation:

Option B: Hemosiderosis: Hemosiderosis refers to the deposition of iron in tissues as hemosiderin, which occurs following hemorrhage, but it does not result in black pigmentation.

Option C: Lipofuscin: Lipofuscin is an aging pigment that accumulates within cells due to the oxidation of unsaturated fatty acids, and it has a brownish-yellow color, not black.

Option D: Melanin: Melanin is a dark pigment found in the skin, hair, and eyes, and is not typically found in the lymph nodes unless there is a melanoma metastasis, which is not indicated in this patient.

Educational Objective:

Black pigmentation of the hilar lymph node in a patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung and a history of smoking is most likely due to anthracotic pigment. This benign condition is associated with the accumulation of carbon particles in the lungs and lymph nodes.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/e p509)

choices.text: Diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in asbestosis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Emphysema

Option C:

Emphysema: Emphysema is not a typical feature of asbestosis. Emphysema is a condition characterized by the destruction of the air sacs in the lungs, leading to decreased elasticity and airflow obstruction. It is more commonly associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and smoking.

Explanation:

Option A: Diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis: This is a characteristic feature of asbestosis. Prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers can lead to the development of diffuse interstitial fibrosis in the lungs.

Option B: Fibrous pleural thickening: Asbestos exposure can cause fibrous thickening of the pleura, the thin membrane covering the lungs and lining the chest cavity. This is a common finding in asbestosis.

Option D: Calcific pleural plaques: Calcific pleural plaques are a characteristic finding in asbestosis. These plaques are areas of calcification on the pleura and are often considered a hallmark of asbestos exposure.

Educational Objective:

Emphysema is not a feature typically associated with asbestosis but is instead related to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and smoking, due to the destruction of air sacs and decreased lung elasticity.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 694)

questions.text: Which interstitial lung disease is caused by organic dust?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Byssinosis

 Option C:

Byssinosis is an interstitial lung disease caused by exposure to organic dust, particularly from cotton, flax, or hemp. It's associated with occupational exposure in textile workers and leads to chest tightness and other respiratory symptoms, worsening at the beginning of the workweek.

Explanation:

Option A: Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of inorganic silica dust, leading to a fibrotic reaction in the lungs. It is not related to organic dust but to mineral dust exposure, commonly seen in mining.

Option B: Asbestosis results from the inhalation of asbestos fibers, which are also inorganic. It leads to interstitial fibrosis but is again not due to organic dust.

Option D: Anthracosis is caused by the accumulation of carbon dust in the lungs and is typically related to pollution or coal mining. It is a form of pneumoconiosis but not caused by organic dust.

Educational Objective:

Byssinosis is an interstitial lung disease caused by the inhalation of organic dust from materials like cotton, flax, or hemp, leading to characteristic occupational lung disease with inflammation and fibrosis of the lung's interstitial spaces.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 690)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is typically associated with fibrotic changes predominantly in the lower lobes of the lungs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Asbestosis

 

Option B:

 

Asbasetosis typically presents with diffuse interstitial fibrosis in the lower lobes/base of the lungs.  It is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers over an extended period. The asbestos fibers, once inhaled, can lead to the formation of fibrous tissue in the lungs, causing interstitial fibrosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: Silicosis, on the other hand, is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica dust. It typically results in nodular lesions and fibrosis, with a predilection for the upper lobes of the lungs.

 

Option A: In the case of tuberculosis (TB), it commonly affects the upper lobes of the lungs, and lower lung involvement is less common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with interstitial fibrosis predominantly in the lower lobes of the lungs, which contrasts with the upper lobe involvement seen in conditions like silicosis and tuberculosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 695)

questions.text: Pleural calcification is found in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hemothorax

Option B:

Hemothorax: Hemothorax is the accumulation of blood in the pleural cavity. It is not typically associated with pleural calcification.

Explanation:

Option A: Asbestosis: Asbestosis is associated with pleural plaques, which are areas of fibrous tissue on the pleura, but it can also lead to pleural calcification over time. Therefore, pleural calcification can be found in asbestosis.

Option C: Tuberculous pleural effusion: Tuberculous pleural effusion is related to tuberculosis and involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. Pleural calcification may be seen as a feature of tuberculous pleural effusion.

Option D: Coal worker pneumoconiosis: Coal worker pneumoconiosis, also known as black lung disease, is associated with the inhalation of coal dust. It may lead to pleural calcification.

Educational Objective:

Pleural calcification is not typically associated with hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural cavity, whereas conditions such as asbestosis, tuberculous pleural effusion, and coal worker pneumoconiosis can all lead to pleural calcification.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 732)

questions.text: Which condition is Caplan’s syndrome associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoconiosis

 

Option B:

 

Pneumoconiosis refers to a group of lung diseases caused by the inhalation of certain dusts and includes diseases like silicosis, asbestosis, and coal worker's pneumoconiosis. Caplan’s syndrome is an association of rheumatoid arthritis with pneumoconiosis, particularly seen in coal miners.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: COPD, or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, is a common respiratory condition, primarily due to smoking, that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs and includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis. It is not associated with Caplan's syndrome.

 

Option C: Pulmonary edema is a condition characterized by excess fluid in the lungs and is usually related to heart conditions or acute injury, not associated with Caplan’s syndrome.

 

Option D: Bronchial asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchospasm. Asthma is not linked to Caplan’s syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoconiosis is the condition associated with Caplan's syndrome, which is the coexistence of rheumatoid arthritis and a pneumoconiosis, often coal worker's pneumoconiosis.

 

Key Features:

 

  • Seen in coal miners or silica-exposed workers with Rheumatoid Arthritis
  • Radiologically: Multiple, well-defined, round nodules in both lungs
  • Histologically: Nodules show central necrosis surrounded by macrophages and fibrosis
  • Associated with positive rheumatoid factor (RF)

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th /688)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea and a history of occupational exposure to certain substances. Physical examination reveals inspiratory crackles, and chest imaging shows interstitial fibrosis predominantly in the lower lung fields. Pulmonary function tests demonstrate a restrictive pattern. Additionally, the patient is at an increased risk for developing lung cancer. Which of the following occupational lung diseases is most strongly associated with an elevated risk of lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Asbestosis

 

 Option A:

 

Asbestosis is caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers and is highly associated with an increased risk of lung cancer, including mesothelioma, which affects the pleural lining of the lungs. It's the only pneumoconiosis that is both a tumor initiator and promoter.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Silicosis results from the inhalation of silica dust and is associated with an increased risk of developing lung diseases, including chronic bronchitis and pulmonary fibrosis, and also increases the risk of lung cancer, but not as strongly as asbestosis.

 

Option C: Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease," is caused by exposure to cotton dust in textile workers. It leads to chest tightness and respiratory issues, but its link to lung cancer is not as significant as with asbestosis.

 

Option D: Anthracosis, commonly seen in coal workers, is due to the inhalation of coal dust. It can lead to black lung disease, but similar to silicosis and byssinosis, its association with lung cancer is less direct compared to asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is the occupational lung disease with the strongest association with an increased risk of lung cancer, particularly mesothelioma, due to the inhalation of asbestos fibers.

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 691)

questions.text: In the context of asbestos exposure, which asbestos fiber type is least likely to induce mesothelioma, a malignancy affecting the linings of the lungs, abdomen, or heart?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Crysotile

Option B:

Crysotile asbestos is the most common form used in industry and has a serpentine structure. Although it is less potent than amphibole asbestos in causing mesothelioma, it is still associated with a risk of causing this malignancy.

Explanation:

Option A: Amphibole asbestos fibers are less common than chrysotile but are more pathogenic, with a higher risk of inducing mesothelioma due to their shape and biopersistence.

Option C: Amosite, a type of amphibole asbestos, is associated with a significantly higher risk of mesothelioma compared to chrysotile due to its greater biopersistence and fiber geometry.

Option D: Tremolite, another amphibole asbestos fiber, is also associated with a high risk of mesothelioma. Like other amphiboles, its physical characteristics make it more pathogenic than chrysotile.

Educational Objective:

Among the various types of asbestos fibers, chrysotile has the least association with the development of mesothelioma due to its different physical properties compared to amphibole forms like amosite and tremolite.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 695)

questions.text: The following does not occur with asbestosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methaemoglobinemia

Option A:

Methemoglobinemia is a condition where hemoglobin is oxidized, reducing its ability to carry oxygen. It is not directly related to asbestos exposure.

Explanation:

Option B: Pneumoconiosis refers to lung diseases caused by inhalation of various types of dust, including asbestos. Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure.

Option C: Pleural mesothelioma is strongly associated with asbestos exposure. It is a type of cancer that affects the pleura (the lining of the lungs and chest cavity) and is a well-known complication of asbestos exposure.

Option D: Pleural calcification is a characteristic finding in individuals with a history of asbestos exposure. Asbestos fibers can lead to the formation of pleural plaques, which are areas of fibrous thickening and calcification on the pleura.

Educational Objective:

Methemoglobinemia is a condition of oxidized hemoglobin leading to impaired oxygen delivery and is not related to asbestos exposure.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 695)

choices.text: Progression of lesion even after stopping exposure to asbestos
Nodular lesions involving upper lobe
Asbestos bodies in sputum

questions.text: Asbestosis of the lung is associated with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nodular lesions involving upper lobes

 Option C:

Asbestosis typically presents with diffuse interstitial fibrosis in the lower lobes/base of the lungs. Nodular lesions involving the upper lobe are not a typical feature of asbestosis. Instead, upper lobe involvement is more commonly associated with silicosis.

Explanation:

Option A: Mesothelioma: Asbestosis is associated with an increased risk of developing mesothelioma, a type of cancer that affects the mesothelial lining of the lungs and other organs.

Option B: Progression of lesion even after stopping exposure to asbestos: Asbestosis can continue to progress even after exposure to asbestos has ceased. The disease is characterized by the development of fibrosis in the lungs, and the progression may persist even after the individual is no longer exposed to asbestos.

Option D: Asbestos bodies in sputum: Asbestos bodies are ferruginous bodies coated with iron-containing proteins and are often found in the sputum of individuals with asbestosis.

Educational objective:

Nodular lesions involving the upper lobes are not characteristic of asbestosis but are commonly associated with silicosis, whereas asbestosis typically presents with diffuse interstitial fibrosis in the lower lobes and may be associated with mesothelioma, lesion progression post-exposure, and the presence of asbestos bodies in sputum.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 690)
